title: The `unfold` and `apply` tactics

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.neg_one_smul_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (v : V) : -1 • v = -v

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.smul_zero_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (a : K) : a • 0 = 0

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.subspace_contains_zero
lemmas.altTitle:
{K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) {W}
  (hW : LinearAlgebraGame.isSubspace W) : 0 ∈ W

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.subspace_neg
lemmas.altTitle:
{K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) {W}
  (hW : LinearAlgebraGame.isSubspace W) (x : V) (a✝ : x ∈ W) : -x ∈ W

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.zero_smul_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (w : V) : 0 • w = 0

lemmas.name: MulAction.mul_smul
lemmas.altTitle: {α} {β} [Monoid α] [MulAction α β] (x y : α) (b : β) : (x * y) • b = x • y • b

lemmas.name: Nat.add_succ
lemmas.altTitle: (n m : ℕ) : n + Nat.succ m = Nat.succ (n + m)

lemmas.name: add_right_cancel
lemmas.altTitle: {G} [Add G] [IsRightCancelAdd G] {a b c} (a✝ : a + b = c + b) : a = c

lemmas.name: add_smul
lemmas.altTitle: {R} {M} [Semiring R] [AddCommMonoid M] [Module R M] (r s : R) (x : M) : (r + s) • x = r • x + s • x

lemmas.name: le_iff_exists_add
lemmas.altTitle: {α} [CanonicallyOrderedAddCommMonoid α] {a b} : a ≤ b ↔ ∃ c, b = a + c

lemmas.name: one_smul
lemmas.altTitle: (M : Type u_1) {α} [Monoid M] [MulAction M α] (b : α) : 1 • b = b

lemmas.name: smul_add
lemmas.altTitle: {M} {A} [AddZeroClass A] [DistribSMul M A] (a : M) (b₁ b₂ : A) : a • (b₁ + b₂) = a • b₁ + a • b₂

lemmas.name: symm
lemmas.altTitle: {α} {r} [IsSymm α r] {a b} (a✝ : r a b) : r b a

introduction:
In this level, we will learn the `unfold` and `apply` tactics. Our goal is to prove `(P → Q) → (¬ Q → ¬ P)`,
which looks very messy and difficult, but it can be slowly unfolded and broken down into simple steps.

The first tactic we will need is `unfold`. You may notice the `¬` symbol appearing multiple times in
the goal. This symbol means "Not", so `¬P` means "not P", or that P is false. In Lean, this is
encoded as `P → False`.

### Unfold
The `unfold` tactic will unfold definitions. Think of it as a big `rw` tactic that rewrites something
with it's definition everywhere. In this level, `unfold Not` will replace all the `¬ P`s with `P → False`.

We know how to deal with statements of the form `P → Q` in the goal, but what happens if we have them
as hypotheses? In this case, we will need the `apply` tactic.

### Apply
The `apply` tactic applies a hypothesis of the form `P → Q` to the goal. If your goal is `Q`, and
you have a hypothesis `h: P → Q`, `apply h` will change the goal to `P`.

### Combining hypotheses
Another way to use `h: P → Q` hypotheses is that if you also have another hypothesis  `h2: P`,
`h h2` will be a proof of `Q`. So, if you have these two hypotheses, and your goal is `Q`, `exact h h2`
will solve the goal.
descrFormat: example (P Q : Prop) : (P → Q) → (¬ Q → ¬ P)  := by
conclusion:
This theorem shows that a statement `P → Q` implies its contrapositive `¬Q → ¬P`. In fact, these
two statements are the same, and you can prove `(P → Q) ↔ (¬ Q → ¬ P)`

Also, instead of writing intro three times, you can write `intros h1 h2 h3`, and that will be the
same as `intro h1; intro h2; intro h3`.
